name: Phil Ochs
description:
'''Philip David Ochs''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|oʊ|k|s}}; December 19, 1940 – April 9, 1976) was an American songwriter, [[protest song|protest singer]] (or, as he preferred, "topical singer"), and [[Political Activist|political activist]]. Ochs was known for his sharp wit, sardonic humor, and political commentary. He wrote about 200 songs in the 1960s and 1970s and released eight albums.

Ochs performed at many political events, including the [[1968 Democratic National Convention]], mass demonstrations sponsored by the [[National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam]], [[civil rights movement|civil rights]] rallies, student events, and [[Labour movement|organized labor]] events. He performed at some benefits for free. Ochs initially described himself as a "left social democrat" but grew more radical after the [[1968 Democratic National Convention protests|police riots at the 1968 Democratic National Convention]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2025}}

After years of prolific writing in the 1960s, Ochs' mental stability declined in the 1970s. His mental health problems included [[Depression (mood)|depression]], [[bipolar disorder]], and [[alcoholism]]. He died by [[suicide]] on April 9, 1976.

Ochs's influences included [[Woody Guthrie]], [[Pete Seeger]], [[Buddy Holly]], [[Elvis Presley]], [[Bob Gibson (musician)|Bob Gibson]], [[Faron Young]], and [[Merle Haggard]]. His best-known songs include "[[I Ain't Marching Anymore (song)|I Ain't Marching Anymore]]", "When I'm Gone", "Changes", "[[Crucifixion (song)|Crucifixion]]", "[[Draft Dodger Rag]]", "[[Love Me, I'm a Liberal]]", "[[Outside of a Small Circle of Friends]]", "[[Power and the Glory]]", "[[There but for Fortune (song)|There but for Fortune]]", and "[[The War Is Over (Phil Ochs song)|The War Is Over]]".
